prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tuning1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First part of the line survey covering about 84-88 and 96-100 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution is about 1/3 of the expected spectral line width. The experience we gained with our Cycles 0 and 1 data with the same spectral resolution on the same source shows that this spectral resolution is sufficient for the LTE analysis (used to model and identify the detected lines) to work well. Our previous ALMA project (EMoCA) led to the secure first detection of a branched alkyl molecule in the interstellar medium (Belloche et al. 2014, Science, 345, 1584).

The requested angular resolution is needed to get a good coupling to the compact emission expected from butyl cyanide, the main target molecule of this project. Based on our astrochemical model and assumptions about the structure of Sgr B2(N2), we expect this emission to have a size on the order of 0.7''. The requested angular resolution will also resolve the East-West velocity gradient of the other hot core, Sgr B2(N1), and will thus help lowering the confusion level in this (stronger) source, possibly enabling the detection of new complex organic molecules there too.
This project focuses on the emission of complex organic molecules that reside in the two hot cores Sgr B2(N1) and (N2). The typical size of this hot-core emission is smaller than 2'', and depends on the molecule and the upper energy level of the transition. The emission of some simpler molecules is expected to be more extended, but these molecules are not the focus of our project.

We want to improve the sensitivity to compact emission by a factor of about 3 compared to our previous Cycles 0 and 1 projects for which the achieved rms noise level (after self-calibration) was on the order of 3 mJy. The goal of the project is to detect faint lines of complex organic molecules, down to the 3 sigma level, so the S/N will be as low as 3 for the faintest lines. The peak flux we indicate above (10 mJy) arbitrarily corresponds to a line that would be barely detected in our Cycle 0 and 1 data.

Obtaining a spectral survey with a large frequency coverage is crucial for this project because the secure detection of a complex molecule relies on the identification of a large number of transitions of this molecule. The spectral resolution cannot be degraded because it is just sufficient to resolve the expected line widths of 5 km/s. Therefore, the data rate cannot be reduced without severely affecting the outcome of the project.

Obtaining a spectral survey with a large frequency coverage is crucial for this project because the secure detection of a complex molecule relies on the identification of a large number of transitions of this molecule. The requested spectral resolution is just sufficient to resolve the expected line width of 5 km/s and thus cannot be degraded. The single polarisation mode is the only mode offering such a large bandwidth with a spectral resolution still sufficient to resolve the lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tuning5

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The search for complex organic molecules (COMs) in the interstellar medium (ISM) will be a primary focus of ALMA science. Our recent detection of a branched alkyl molecule in the ISM with ALMA has opened a new domain in the structures available to the chemistry of star-forming regions, beyond simple chains. Our astrochemical model was recently expanded to include branched isomers, and indicates that branched molecules may be dominant in star-forming regions where the chemistry is of sufficient complexity. We propose to perform a direct observational test of this hypothesis, in order to determine both the degree and the manner in which chemical complexity evolves during star formation. We propose to search for n-butyl cyanide and its three branched isomers toward Sgr B2(N), the most fruitful target for new detections of COMs in the ISM. The discovery of biologically-relevant molecules in the ISM is of high scientific impact, and has proved to be of broad appeal to the public and the media. The combination of our established and productive methodologies with ALMA's unique spectral sensitivity is an ideal match to delve into the newly-discovered chemistry of branched COMs.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Chemistry, University of Virginia
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
